intro: Pyxidium silvestre, commonly known as the wild bellflower, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to temperate regions of Europe. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Pyxidium silvestre is often found in woodlands, meadows, and along streambanks, where it thrives in moist, well-drained soil.
